title: 112_hr2624
content: The "Universal College Credit Act" is introduced as a new section (SEC. 25E) in the Internal Revenue Code of 1986, providing universal college credit. The "Universal College Credit Act" (SEC. 25E) allows individuals to claim a tax credit for qualified tuition and related expenses paid during the taxable year. The credit is limited to $5,000 per individual and can only be claimed for 4 years of undergraduate education and 6 years of graduate education. The "Universal College Credit Act" allows individuals to claim a tax credit for qualified tuition and related expenses paid during the taxable year. The credit is limited to $5,000 per individual and can only be claimed for 4 years of undergraduate education or 6 years of graduate education. No credit is allowed if another provision in the tax code already provides a benefit for the same expenses. The tax credit for qualified tuition and related expenses under the "Universal College Credit Act" applies to individuals, their spouses, or dependents at eligible educational institutions. Expenses for sports, games, hobbies, and nonacademic fees are not included in the credit. The tax credit for qualified tuition and related expenses under the "Universal College Credit Act" applies to individuals, their spouses, or dependents at eligible educational institutions. Expenses for sports, games, hobbies, and nonacademic fees are not included in the credit. The amount of qualified tuition and related expenses for an individual is adjusted for scholarships and section 529 distributions. An eligible educational institution is defined as an institution described in section 102 of the Act. The term 'undergraduate education expenses' refers to qualified tuition and related expenses paid by the taxpayer for an individual enrolled in an undergraduate course of study. 'Graduate education expenses' are for a graduate or professional course of study. Eligible institutions must be described in section 102 of the Higher Education Act of 1965 and eligible for participation in a program under title IV of the Act. The amount of qualified tuition and related expenses for an individual may be reduced by certain payments such as qualified scholarships, educational assistance allowances, and payments for educational expenses. The section allows for exclusion of educational expenses from gross income under US law. Taxpayers can elect not to apply this section for a taxable year. Coordination with exclusion for income from US savings bonds used for higher education is also addressed. Sec. 25E introduces universal college credit, with amendments applying to taxable years after the enactment of the Act.
